column2: the Land of the Dead that Live
column3: was the name given by the Eldar to the region surrounding the isle of Tol Galen in southern Ossiriand
column4: where Beren and Lúthien lived after their return from the dead. It is told that the country was exceptionally beautiful
column5: even reminding of the blessed land of Valinor.

column1: Dor Firn-i-Guinar is the name appearing in the published The Silmarillion
column2: apparently consisting of the Sindarin elements dor "land" + firn "dead" + in "who
column3: that" + cuinar "live".http://www.tolkiendil.com/langues/english/i-lam_arth/compound_sindarin_names Compound Sindarin Names in Middle-earth at http://www.tolkiendil.com Tolkiendil.com (accessed 10 November 2011)

column2: J.R.R. Tolkien experimented with many variations on how to translate Land of the Dead that Live: I·Cuilwarthon
column6: and Gwerth-i-guinar. (entries for Land of the Dead that Live) In a 1972 letter
column7: Tolkien used the name Dor Gyrth i chuinar.
